awd_titl_txt: Wave effects in upper ocean turbulence models
awd_abstract_narration:
Wind is the major driving force for the upper ocean. The structure and intensity of turbulent mixing in the surface layer of the ocean vary greatly in the presence of steep wind waves, and existing numerical models are not always very accurate in their predictions. This study seeks to improve the representation of surface wave effects in numerical models of upper-ocean mixing and expand the empirical basis for validating these models against mixed layer turbulence measurements. Existing data from freely drifting instruments that move up and down the well mixed layer of the upper ocean will be analyzed to yield new information about the vertical structure of turbulence under a wide range of wave conditions. Virtual drifters simulated in very high resolution numerical models will be used to develop new analysis methods and to enhance the limited observational data sets. The study will aid comparisons among competing theories on wave-turbulence interaction by expanding and refining the metrics of model-data comparisons.  Insights on wave-turbulence interaction will lead to new mixing parameterizations, that can be validated against small-scale turbulence measurements, and ultimately enhance the skill of ocean circulation models. The dissemination of drifter measurements and model code will also benefit other approaches to parameterizing wave effects.  The ability of the improved closure models to reproduce the observed anisotropy of mixed layer turbulence, and the homogeneity of momentum and scalar profiles, will be of interest in many physical and biogeochemical oceanographic fields, ranging from climate modeling to coastal sediment transport and oil spill prediction. Implementing the improvements in a widely used modeling framework, the General Ocean Turbulence Model (GOTM) will facilitate usage of these results by a broad range of ocean modelers. This project will promote study at a unique nexus between engineering and geophysics and supports a graduate research associate to work on drifter data analysis and model-data comparisons. The project will contribute new material to the investigators' ongoing individual outreach activities through public school classrooms and science fairs.


The second moment closure (SMC) model developments build on recent advances that include Craik-Leibovich (CL) vortex forcing fully in a 'quasi-equilibrium' SMC, adopting a momentum flux closure with a component down the Stokes drift gradient and an inhomogeneous near-surface pressure-strain closure. The CL forcing Reynolds stress terms and new turbulence closures will be applied to modify the larger class of 'weak-equilibrium' SMCs for Langmuir turbulence. These will be implemented and evaluated in the GOTM framework, including the modeled interaction of Langmuir turbulence and surface wave breaking. New analysis of existing high-quality Lagrangian float data will provide profiles of kinetic energy components, turbulent length scales, large-eddy kinetic energy dissipation rates and near-surface Lagrangian statistics that can discriminate between theories for surface -wave forcing of boundary-layer turbulence. New large eddy simulations (LES) will contain embedded virtual floats, and will include forcing by stochastic wave breaking at float- and model-resolved scales. Using this LES, the researchers will develop new data analysis methods and guide SMC modifications for wave forcing. The new near-surface closure for CL forcing will be combined with similar treatments of buoyant production in of turbulent covariance in SMC for convection with nonlocal gradient closures. LES results and float data will be used to verify and tune SMC models. Modified SMC model code and float data test cases will be distributed for public availability via the GOTM framework.

por.por_cntn:
This study has sought improve the representation of surface wave effects in models of upper-ocean mixing, and to expand the basis for testing these models against mixed layer turbulence measurements. Towards improving the models, we have advanced a category of formulations called Second Moment Closure (SMC), used to represent mixing by small-scale (< 10 m) turbulence in ocean models that resolve ocean dynamics only down about 1km scale or larger. We have modified their formulation to more fully account for the forces impressed upon currents and turbulence by surface gravity waves. This interaction with turbulence in the upper ocean generates longitudinal down-wind rolls called Langmuir circulation that are highly efficient at ventilating the ocean mixed layer. We have further advanced these models by implementing or disseminating these improvements within the ocean modeling frameworks of two different ocean modeling communities, one using the General Ocean Turbulence Model (GOTM) and one using a variant of the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS).

To improve the representation of wave-driven processes in the upper ocean models, we worked towards developing better, ocean-appropriate empirical non-dimensional profiles of the vertical gradients of scalars like heat, or of turbulent kinetic energy components like W^2, the covariance of vertical velocity W. In the atmospheric counterpart of ocean boundary layer mixing, long-standing non-dimensional empirical profiles unify observations from disparate forcing environments and provide a systematic basis to parameterize and validate near-surface mixing against large and varying observational data sets. However, transfer of atmospheric surface layer behavior into ocean boundary studies often fails, due to the effect of different mixing processes driven by surface waves, such as Langmuir turbulence. Numerical models resolving mixed layer ocean turbulence have been used to develop better SMC models of turbulent mixing, but those Large Eddy Simulations (LES) results rest unsteadily on a simplified phase-averaged representation of the effect of surface waves, and rely heavily on their own parameterization of unresolved turbulence right next to the surface.

To improve the empirical basis for parameterizing turbulence, we have therefore worked to distill such 'unifying' empirical surface layer relationships from archived data sets of upper ocean measurements. We were surprised to find that the small unstable overhang of cold water is large enough to be well-measured by accurate modern thermistors at a mooring, and we were able, with some careful data analysis, to resolve the dependence of the profile vertical gradient of temperature in the surface layer upon depth and dimensional surface forcing scales, like wind stress and buoyancy flux. This turned out to be very clearly different to atmospheric scaling relations, and generally consistent with predictions from simplified versions of the SMC of Langmuir turbulence. Given success in this approach we have found similar results when this analysis is applied to the more challenging data set of turbulent vertical velocities measured from Lagrangian floats, floats that move vertically with the water in the ocean mixed layer and provide statistics on vertical velocity obtained from the time derivative of pressure at the float. Since these floats naturally remove most of the vertical velocity signal due to surface waves, this has permitted us to isolate the vertical turbulent kinetic energy and find consistent nondimensional profiles that allow us to predict this crucial element of vertical mixing across a wide range of ocean forcing conditions.


This project has contributed new model physics to ocean mixing predictions within several modeling frameworks, and has developed two important empirical scaling predictions for surface layer profiles to guide and constrain models of wave-turbulence interaction and enhanced mixing in the ocean. It has contributed to three publications, several Conference and workshop presentations, and advanced a graduate student through Masters to PhD candidacy. The student is anticipated to defend a PhD, spring of 2022, and submit another paper on the surface profiles of vertical turbulent kinetic energy, as well as additional thesis work on mixed layer shear profiles measured from Lagrangian floats.
